{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3414509,"name":"Falon Clark","username":"Tatiman-Dev","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tatiman-dev/{size}/236095_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-11T00:43:33.688Z","cooked":"

Hello! Me and my team are interested in utilizing AdvantageKit for logging, replay, and hardware abstraction in the coming season. I’m interested in getting information on some of the disadvantages (from a performance perspective) of using advantagekit. One of our mentors does not want to use AK largely because of performance issues, and a dislike of it’s “Shims” that (from my understanding) modify WPILIB behavior. I’d like more information on the performance of AdvantageKit versus other logging options like DogLog and DataLog, as well as information on what can be done to alleviate performance problems if they arise.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-08-11T00:43:33.688Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":52,"reads":197,"readers_count":196,"score":304.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":469679,"topic_slug":"performance-implications-of-advantagekit","display_username":"Falon Clark","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57393,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"The Kotlin Guy"},"post_url":"/t/performance-implications-of-advantagekit/469679/1","custom_user_title":"The Kotlin Guy","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3414521,"name":"Jonah Bonner","username":"jonahb55","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jonahb55/{size}/194474_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-11T02:31:55.022Z","cooked":"

I’ll do my best to address both of these concerns.

Tatiman-Dev:

performance issues

One of the consequences of AdvantageKit’s design as a log replay framework is that it will always need to log a larger amount of data than strictly necessary for a simple logging library. Therefore, one of our core requirements when designing AdvantageKit was that it should have a minimal performance impact — we accomplished this by reading replayable HAL data via a shared memory buffer (rather than slow JNI calls) and handling all data encoding and file/network IO from a background thread.

In practice, this means that the periodic work done by AdvantageKit each loop cycle takes ~1-2ms — we considered this an acceptable tradeoff for the benefits of log replay. For reference, in our last Einstein match in 2024 the average time spend logging per loop cycle was 1.56ms with a 99th percentile of 1.95ms. Since all IO (reading and writing) is handled off the main thread, this means that the execution of user code is very stable and cannot be disrupted by crashes or other issues with data flow.

Memory usage is another common concern with many libraries, but is unfortunately difficult to quantify (it changes depending on usage, object allocations can cause issues beyond just total usage, etc). This tends to not be a major concern on the RIO 2 regardless, but any decently complex robot project on the RIO 1 is likely to benefit from the steps shown here in the WPILib docs. AdvantageKit is likely to be a larger contributor to memory pressure than simpler alternatives (again this is hard to quantify), but as before this is somewhat inherent given the extra features it is designed to provide.

WPILib’s DataLogManager is designed to be more performant in general since it is very minimal, but comparing performance becomes tricky once you add modern conveniences like NetworkTables and annotation logging. Ultimately there are a lot of variables at play depending on exactly how you use each option, but in general I don’t think you’ll see significant performance issues with any of the modern logging libraries. The best advice I can give is to try out some different options and evaluate which best suits your needs (the offseason is a perfect time to do this).

Tatiman-Dev:

dislike of it’s “shims” that modify WPILib behavior

Log replay depends on making the execution of the robot code deterministic, meaning that any data used by the robot code (including from WPILib) must be logged such that it can be replayed. The current design of WPILib makes this impossible for us to achieve, since most values can change in the middle of a loop cycle. The most notable example is the FPGA timestamp — if you’re curious about why the default behavior is a problem for log replay, I’d recommend reading over this post on the AdvantageKit CD thread as well as the replies to it.

We “shim” (replace) several WPILib classes so that we can control the values returned from them. AdvantageKit utilizes these shims to prevent values from changing in the middle of loop cycles and ensure that the data provided to the robot code exactly matches the data in the log. Beyond locking the data to the loop cycle, the behavior of these classes is unchanged.

The issue with the shims is primarily one of maintenance, since we need to keep up with changes made to WPILib for them to remain functional. While we have some tools to assist with this, there have been occasional times that issues slip through. However, we are hopeful that those issues will soon be in the past: we’re working to make improvements to WPILib’s HAL which will enable AdvantageKit to function without shims next year. This should alleviate any concerns that might remain.

Tatiman-Dev:

logging, replay, and hardware abstraction

As a final note, these are all very isolated objectives and it’s important to evaluate how much you care about each one. Most logging libraries (like DataLogManager) are focused only on logging. AdvantageKit is focused on logging and replay, and we recommend structuring projects via hardware abstraction. But hardware abstraction is implemented completely in user code and doesn’t actually require AdvantageKit (the reverse is also true, though less common). We started using IO layers for subsystems before creating AdvantageKit, and I know there are teams that still follow this model (i.e. use IO layers via a non-replay logging framework). I don’t know if that fits your needs, but it’s another option if you’re interested in using hardware abstraction.
